titleStmt.title: The Kings Maiesties letter intercepted by the commissioners attending his Majesty. (A copie whereof was sent to the Parliament.) and Mr. Mungo Murrey apprehended, who was appointed by the King to deliver it to Montrel; the French embassador, who is going over to the Queen to France. And a list of the jests of all the severall places where His Majestie hath lain, and is to lie everie day between Newcastle and Holmby House. Also the maner of the Scots marching home into Scotland, with other newes from the court, and Newcastle. Perused, and (being examined) is appointed to be printed and published, according to order of Parliament, Feb. 9. 1646.
titleStmt.author: Sammel, L.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 8 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

And a list of the jests of all the severall places where His Majestie hath lain, and is to lie everie day between Newcastle and Holmby House. Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Great Britain -- History -- Civil War, 1642-1649 -- Early works to 1800.

div.p: The Kings Maie≈øties LETTER INTERCEPTED By the Commi≈øsioners attending his MAJESTY. (A copie whereof was ≈øent to the PARLIAMENT.) AND Mr. MUNGO MURREY apprehended, who was appointed by the KING to deliver it to Montrel, the French Emba≈ø≈øador, Who is going over to the QVEEN to FRANCE.
And a Li≈øt of the Je≈øts of all the ≈øeverall places where his Maje≈øtie hath lain, and is to lie everie day between Newca≈øtle and Holmby hou≈øe.
Al≈øo the maner of the Scots marching home into Scotland, with other newes from the Court, and Newca≈øtle.
PEru≈øed, and (being examined) is appointed to be Printed and Publi≈øhed, according to Order of Parliament, Feb. 9. 1646.
LONDON: Printed by A. COE, neer Cripplegate, 1647.

div.head: The Kings Maie≈øties Letter intercepted, By the Commi≈øsioners attending his Maje≈øty.
A Copie whereof was ≈øent to the PARLIAMENT.
div.p:
YOURS by the Po≈øt I have received, for which I thank you, and in demon≈øtration of it, give you this return. Sir, I ≈øuppo≈øe you cannot want intelligence how things are managed here, and my labour might be ≈øpared; how≈øoever, I cannot but a≈ø≈øure you, the Scots are all departed; and had I not ≈øeen them march, I could never have beleeved, either their number to have been in the Kingdom, nor their ≈øad behaviour upon their departing: yet I impute it not to the Nation,
nor the Army, but to particular per≈øons therof, though ≈øome Officers co ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ive to „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , I dare affirme, that of all the Hor≈øe I ever ≈øaw in this Kingdome, ≈øince the fir≈øt marching from Keinton, I never ≈øaw ≈øo many b ‚Ä¢ ave Hor≈øe together, at lea≈øt ≈øix thou≈øand. The Officers all marched w ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ h naked ≈øwords, but their Hor≈øes were not b ‚Ä¢ e; for they were all ‚Ä¢ ded and cloathed to purpo≈øe. But they have been ≈øo reall in the main, that I will goe backward and hide their nakedne≈ø≈øe.
The V ‚Ä¢ ce Admi ‚Ä¢ als Ship is ≈øtill in Lieth Road in Sco ‚Ä¢ land, ≈øtopping „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ , nor doth the winde ≈øerve for her to come away as ‚Ä¢ et.
The Holland man of Warre at Tinmouth, longs as much to be gone, as we to have him, but is windbound. The Vice Adm ‚Ä¢ rall waits on her in the Con≈øtant Warwick, and hath two more with him.
Ye≈øterday wee heard of the Fellow≈øhip without the Barre, but a ≈øtorm came up about three a clock, and put her off to Sea.

There dined aboord the Vice Admirall Ship, Adjutant Generall Deate, of the Army, the Judge Advocate, Commi≈ø≈øioner Potter, Major Smith, and Captain Skippon. Major Smith received Tinmouth Ca≈øtle, and is there at pre≈øent. Who ≈øhall be governor of Tinmouth Ca≈øtle, I ≈øhall advert ‚Ä¢ ≈øe you in my next.

On Saturday la≈øt the Engli≈øh Commi≈ø≈øioners took ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of his Maje≈øty, and ≈øetled Families: His Maje≈øty took it very ill to have his old Servants taken ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ om him. That (and ≈øome other things which I forbeare at pre≈øent) put his Maje≈øty into an humour that he would not heare Major Ke ‚Ä¢ e preach on the Lords day, although two dayes before he cau≈øed a note to be
≈øent to him to preach, but be applyed him≈øelfe to the Commi≈ø≈øioners, and acquainted them that he would take no notice of it without their Summons.

Then Ma ‚Ä¢ or Keme was appointed to preach, who accordingly came hither to Newca≈øtle on ≈øaturday night; and being come, he ≈øent the ≈øame night to Mr. Mar≈øhal, to know which time of the day he plea≈øed: who ≈øpake with Mr. Keme, and told him, that both he and Mr. C ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ll had had ≈øome p ‚Ä¢ ivate di≈øcour≈øe with the King about it, but that His Maje≈øty was re≈øolved to heare none of them.
And accordingly on that Lords day his Maje≈øty was as good as his word, his Maje≈øtie never came, although much imp ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ tuned by the Earle of Pembroke, the Earle of Denbigh, &c.

His Maje≈øtie hath now other maner of Table and attendance then formerly, a great many hone≈øt godly Courtiers, and good Souldiers, Mr. Harbert, Sir Fnlke Grivill, Captain Mildmay Carver, Mr. Harrington of the Bedchamber, Mr. Dou≈øer, Captain Titus Querrey, &c.
The King ye≈øterday tooke his journey from hence, I have ≈øent you here inclo≈øed a li≈øt of the ≈øeverall places appointed for his quarters every night from hence „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ by Hou≈øe.
The Lord move his Maje≈øties he art to con≈øider what is pa≈øt, and take his journey Heavenward, to act for his glory for the future.

On Munday la≈øt one Mr. Mungo Mur ‚Ä¢ ey,
who hath been a ≈øervant to the King, de≈øired leave of the Commi≈ø≈øioners to take his leave of the King, and ≈øo to go into Scotland: which was granted to him.
The ≈øaid Mr. Mungo Murrey, having thus obtained leave, came to his Maie≈øty, and his Maie≈øty gave him his hand to ki≈ø≈øe, which he did.

But withall ≈øomthing was perceived (by one of the Commi≈øsioners) to be put in Mr. Mungo Murries hand, by the King; who being followed, and by the Commi≈øsioners examined, and ≈øearched, it was found to be aletter, which he was to deliver to Montrel the French Agent.

It was all in Cyphers, ≈øo that nothing could be read of it, but the Commi≈øsioners have ≈øent it to the Parliament to ≈øee if they have keyes to unlock tho≈øe Ciphers, the particulars whereof will be with you fir≈øt, if opened.

Some ≈øuppo≈øe it to be a letter to Montrell, to give him directions in ≈øome things which he ≈øhould do; others gue≈ø≈øe it to be a letter which ≈øhould have been ≈øent to the Queene to France, whither (it is ≈øuppo≈øed) Montrell is immediately to go, from Scotland.
But, the letter is all in figures, and Cyphers, both within, and without, the very Super≈øcription.

This Mr. Mungo Murrey was apprehended, and in Cu≈øtody for two dayes, and then ≈øufficient ≈øecurity was given for his forthcoming within 4. dayes, in ca≈øe that he ≈øhould be demanded, ≈øo he had his liberty. And the Commi≈ø≈øioners have ≈øent up to the Parliament to know their plea≈øure therein.
His Maie≈øtie ≈øet out from hence ye≈øterdaynight in great Pompe, with attendance more befitting and ≈øutable to a King, than ≈øome years pa≈øt. God grant all maybe for the be≈øt, ≈øo prayes

div.head: A li≈øt of the Je≈øts, and ≈øeverall places appointed for His Maje≈øties quarters each day betwixt Newca≈øtle, and Holmby Hou≈øe.
div.p: Wedne≈øday Feb. 3. his Maje≈øty went from Newca≈øtle to Durham.
Thur≈øday Feb. 4. his Maje≈øty pa≈ø≈øed to Bi≈øhop Aukland.
Friday Feb. 5. his Maj. was to pa≈ø≈øe to Richmond.
Saturday Feb. 6. his Maj. was to pa≈ø≈øe to Repton.
Sunday Feb. 7. his Maje≈øty was to ≈øtay at Repton all that day.
Munday Feb. 8. his Maj. was to pa≈ø≈øe to Leeds.
Tue≈øday Feb. 9. his Maj. was to pa≈ø≈øe to Wake field.
Wedne≈øday Feb. 10. his Maj. is to pa≈ø≈øe to Rothram.
Thur≈øday Feb. 11. his Maje≈øtie is to pa≈ø≈øe to Masfield.
Friday Feb. 12. his Maje≈øtie is to pa≈ø≈øe to Nottingham.
Saturday Feb. 13. his Maj. is to pa≈ø≈øe to Leice≈øter.
Sunday Feb. 14. his Maje≈øtie is to ≈øtay all that day at Leice≈øter.
Munday Feb. 15. his Maje≈øty is to go to Holmby Hou≈øe.
